content: A TRILLION dollars of debt nicely monetized, baby! (But only after the red herring of AIG to draw attantion from the astoundingly myopic, economically harmful action.) It has never worked to improve an economy at any time or place in history, but, hey, the wonks of the obamanation are oh-so exclusively brilliant. They'll make it work. Yowzah! What is puffed up as a tax cut for many is paid for by taxpayers, anyway. The cost of that tax cut is higher prices for goods and services that will rapidly suck up the tax cut and leave people even worse off, anyway. Don't fall for the sucker pitch, folks. In the final analysis, all of the involvement of the Congress and the administration is just bullcrap. Unless and until they get spending under control, the numbers are only a front for the game of certain economic degradation. The smoke and mirrors cannot fool everyone: the driving purpose of this nonsense is usurpation of more and more power over our lives.

content: The tax cut wasn't much of a cut for mamy anyway. The $400 ($800 for couples) workers tax credit goes to anyone that has earned income even if they don't normally pay taxes. Last year all my income was exempt due to the combat zone exclusion, but my wife made about $10,000. We got a $5,600 tax "refund" due to EIC and the child tax credit, with zero paid in federal imcome tax. How can the government afford to pay people thousands of dollars in "refund" that are far more than people paid. This year my income is taxable again so if won't happen again, but I still won't pay nearly as much as that refund.
reply: The tax cut wasn't much of a cut for mamy anyway. The $400 ($800 for couples) workers tax credit goes to anyone that has earned income even if they don't normally pay taxes. content: The Texas Republican introduced a bill Wednesday to eliminate all IRS penalties and interest for paying taxes past due. Mosheh Oinounou FOXNews.com Wednesday, January 28, 2009 Americans may be able to rest a little easier this April if Congressman John Carter, R-Texas gets his way. Rep. Carter introduced a bill Wednesday to eliminate all IRS penalties and interest for paying taxes past due. The legislation calls for the creation of what he calls the, "Rangel Rule," -- drawing attention to the recent legal issues of House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Charlie Rangel, D-N.Y., enabling citizens who fail to pay taxes on time to do so later with no additional fees. Rangel, who writes the country's tax policies, acknowledged last fall that he failed to pay thousands in real estate taxes for rental income he earned from a property in the Dominican Republic. As of September 2008 the Harlem Democrat reportedly paid back more than $10,000 in taxes but that did not include any IRS penalties. "Your citizens back home should have the same rights and benefits that come to you as a member of congress. You shouldn't be treated any differently under the law than your citizens back home," Carter said. He added that citizens should receive the "same courtesy" that the IRS is allegedly granting Rangel and Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner, who also recently acknowledged a failure to pay taxes.

It is the unearned handouts of recent times and history back to the 'Great Society' (euphemism extraordinaire ) that comprises the overwhelming prepondernace of the national debt. The duty of any guvmint that dares call itself Constitutional is provide for the common defense and promote (NOT provide) the common welfare. The words are simple. The spendthrift, irresponsible behavior rationalized for feel-good idiocy and usurpation of power is unconstitutional but so deeply ingrained as to ensure weakness of national character to jeopardize the nation's survival.] Americans are in such denial its astounding....They want all their goodies but sure as hell don't want to pay taxes for them, that about right? [Conservatives want to leave money in the hands of the only people who respect it and make it useful: those who eanred it in the first place. Damned sure no jackasses care about the fruits of other people's labors, not really. That underlying selfishness and resentment of successful people, that immorality will spell the doom of economim initiatives that can keep the nation afloat.] The World must be looking at every angle they can possibly look at to free themselves from such an ignorant and stupid ideology. [You just keep deluding yourself. Capitalism is a natural result of people seeking to satisfy their economic needs most efficiently. Collectivism must always be enforced, and that is demonstrated unequivocally by historic events: 1792, 1917, 1933, 1949, 1977. Collectivism, obamanism, is the aborted fetus of control-freak covetousness, greed, and envy.]
title: the Obama Tax Cut??

content: The tax cut wasn't much of a cut for mamy anyway. The $400 ($800 for couples) workers tax credit goes to anyone that has earned income even if they don't normally pay taxes. Last year all my income was exempt due to the combat zone exclusion, but my wife made about $10,000. We got a $5,600 tax "refund" due to EIC and the child tax credit, with zero paid in federal imcome tax. How can the government afford to pay people thousands of dollars in "refund" that are far more than people paid. This year my income is taxable again so if won't happen again, but I still won't pay nearly as much as that refund.

content: The Texas Republican introduced a bill Wednesday to eliminate all IRS penalties and interest for paying taxes past due. Mosheh Oinounou FOXNews.com Wednesday, January 28, 2009 Americans may be able to rest a little easier this April if Congressman John Carter, R-Texas gets his way. Rep. Carter introduced a bill Wednesday to eliminate all IRS penalties and interest for paying taxes past due. The legislation calls for the creation of what he calls the, "Rangel Rule," -- drawing attention to the recent legal issues of House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Charlie Rangel, D-N.Y., enabling citizens who fail to pay taxes on time to do so later with no additional fees. Rangel, who writes the country's tax policies, acknowledged last fall that he failed to pay thousands in real estate taxes for rental income he earned from a property in the Dominican Republic. As of September 2008 the Harlem Democrat reportedly paid back more than $10,000 in taxes but that did not include any IRS penalties. "Your citizens back home should have the same rights and benefits that come to you as a member of congress. You shouldn't be treated any differently under the law than your citizens back home," Carter said. He added that citizens should receive the "same courtesy" that the IRS is allegedly granting Rangel and Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner, who also recently acknowledged a failure to pay taxes.
